newsitem.title: USA: Denver jets to avoid eagles nesting area.
newsitem.headline: Denver jets to avoid eagles nesting area.

text.p: Planes taking off from Denver International Airport will avoid flying over an area where bald eagles roost, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service announced on Friday.

"By making this minor change in the flight path, it is hoped that the eagles will return to their original roosting site that they have used historically," the service's Mountain-Prairie Region Director said in a statement.
The eagles roost at Rocky Mountain Arsenel, a former nerve gas factory that has been turned into a wildlife refuge and is now home to 130 animal species, including white tail deer and prairie dogs.
Since the airport opened two years ago, noise from the jetliners drove the bald eagles from the roost, in violation of the Endangered Species Act.
The interim measures were agreed to by the Federal Aviation Administration and the Fish and Wildlife Service. Scientists will monitor the eagles to see if the measures are working.
Jets will be able to fly over the roost if hazardous weather conditions and public safety require it.
